>Subject: RE: [junit] testing private methods
>
<snip />
>Many people on this list believe that unit testing the public API helps
>the overall design of the system (low coupling, high cohesion, ...), and
>helps decouple solutions from their different implementations.  Many
>interesting points and suggestions have been raised over this issue,
>however, they belong to a Testing&Design discussion, not a Unit Testing
>discussion.

I'm not sure how you can separate the two discussions. Could you tell me how 
Unit Testing can be discussed without discussing its impact on design?

>In the light of Unit Testing, if people want to unit test private
>methods, so be it.
<snip />

Nobody is saying, "Thou shalt not test private methods." But bear in mind 
that JUnit was not built for that purpose. Not only that, its creators feel 
(well Kent, anyway; I don't know how Erich feels) that one of the strengths 
of JUnit is that when the tests become painful to write, there is a tendency 
for the design to have an organic weakness that prevents the testing. As 
Kent says in this case, it's an opportunity to learn about your design.

If you are going to say, "Take your testing/design discussions elsewhere," I 
could easily reply with, "Take your testing-private-methods discussion 
elsewhere -- JUnit doesn't do it." Of course, that is NOT what I am doing. I 
would prefer to have both discussions than neither.

There are other test frameworks that provide support, or will provide 
support, for testing private methods. JUnit does not. I hope it never does. 
That's a personal opinion. If it did, then I would be tempted to use it and 
all of a sudden design is tougher than it needs to be, because one of my 
favorite tools no longer forces me to think.

>The JUnit documentation could point out some of the
>issues and uses of Unit Tests and how they help with the overall design
>of a system (they may already do so, but its been a while since I last
>looked), but the tool is for Unit Testing, and as such, should allow
>people to use it as they will, so long as they know what they are up to.

It's all in how you define "unit". To me, it's the exported methods of a 
class or interface. Kent and Erich may define it differently. Clearly, you 
define it differently. Over the last few years the emphasis appears always 
to have been on testing observable behavior -- you can look it up. By 
definition, private methods do not provide directly observable behavior, and 
are therefore out of JUnit's scope.

You folks can test private methods until your brain pops out, but just don't 
expect JUnit to do it out of the box. It was never designed for that. It was 
never designed for that *on purpose*. I don't know why that is such a big 
deal. You don't like it, that's cool. Use something else, but don't mess up 
JUnit.
